Expanding electricity transmission lines reduces regional price disparities in electricity, boosts renewable energy, and lowers the overall cost of electricity.

Today on VoxDev, Luis E. Gonzales, Koichiro Ito & Mar Reguant outline their work on market integration and the expansion of renewable energy, using evidence from Chile: http://ow.ly/X98H50MxpPl

title: Completing Byzantine history | Discover multiple perspectives on the 11th century

last_post.content:
Who wrote Byzantine history?

@tla / Tara Andrews from the University of Vienna is re-evaluating the history of the Byzantine Empire. By digging for overlooked sources in archives and employing digital tools, she is adding multiple perspectives to the eventful history of the 11th century.

Read more about this exciting digital humanities project here: ⤵

https://rudolphina.univie.ac.at/en/completing-byzantine-history-discover-multiple-perspectives-on-the-11th-century

#digitalhumanities

#compchem #quantumcomputing New #preprint: Extension of the Trotterized Unitary Coupled Cluster to Triple Excitations. Nice work by @HaidarM54481494@twitter.com
https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2212.12462

OK this is actually pretty incredible.

The Smithsonian making 4 million digital items public domain. CC0 means you don't need to give attribution, there's no copyright to worry about, no restrictions on using them in photoshops etc.

It's a huge move for open media for such a big name to be making such a large collection open like this. It's the kind of thing I never really thought we would see start to happen.

https://www.si.edu/openaccess/

New paper "Cross-validatory model selection for Bayesian autoregressions with exogenous regressors" with Alex Cooper, @dan_p_simpson, Lauren Kennedy, and Catherine Forbes

One FAQ is "Can you use LOO or cross-validation in general for time series?" The short answer is "Yes", and I've had a longer answer in CV-FAQ https://avehtari.github.io/modelselection/CV-FAQ.html#9_Can_cross-validation_be_used_for_time_series

Now we have a better answer on what kind of cross-validation is good with timeseries!

#PaperThread #Bayesian #CrossValidation

title: Customize ShareLink appearance with view modifiers

last_post.content:
I've been playing around with the ShareLink in #SwiftUI and realized that apart from providing it a fully custom label, we can also customize its default appearance with view modifiers.

We can set a label style to either show the icon or the text, set image scale or choose a different symbol variant.

I found these modifications useful when trying to place the ShareLink in a custom toolbar.

Also wrote a quick tip on my blog: https://nilcoalescing.com/blog/CustomizeShareLinkAppearance/

#Swift #iOSDev

#NerdHumor #Statistics

title: VSR/Correctness: Preserve Canonical Headers by sentientwaffle · Pull Request #364 · tigerbeetledb/tigerbeetle

last_post.content:
I suspect a reason is it's easier to write a good bug/ticket than it is to write a good comment.

I was thinking about this after seeing https://github.com/tigerbeetledb/tigerbeetle/pull/364/commits/a003666ebf2f53c64b1a5f3d7a5e3bdf9a819a51, which has the kind of comment I was used to seeing at Centaur in bug reports, which I haven't seen systematically anywhere else I've worked.

IMO, tickets/bugs work better for this than commit messages since a lot of useful info can't reasonably be attached to a commit, so putting in commits splits useful info across multiple locations.

I'm not working on my portfolio tracker app https://Stocketa.com anymore these days. Working with stock APIs is such a slog. Good data costs thousands per month and the other providers are bad: constant issues, have to string them together, build your own backend to manage them, etc

Will probably write more about it at some point, but until now here's my TestFlight. Play around and explore, but I probably won't keep it live much longer so I can save some money.

https://testflight.apple.com/join/3dZwTVhS

For each execution of ONE DAY by Dwight Eschliman, a photograph of one static point in the sky is taken every second for 24 consecutive hours. Each of these 86,4000 photographs then becomes a pixel in a larger composition. While ONE DAY is about time, it is also about place. A foggy summer day in San Francisco is going to look very different than a hot and humid summer day in New York. Ultimately, ONE DAY is a portrait of a day and each is unique.

https://www.oneday.eschlimanstudio.com

title: US school runs lights 24/7/365: The smart lights have been broken since 2021

last_post.content:
Massachusetts HS can’t turn off lights <https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2023/01/us-school-runs-lights-24-7-365-the-smart-lights-have-been-broken-since-2021/>. Basically, they installed a ‘smart’ lighting system relying on proprietary software that the vendor no longer supports. The system failed and the lights are stuck permanently on.

And this, friends, is the problem with unfree software.

@HydrePrever I don't have any perfect tools in mind, but I also found RStudio lacking in a lot of ways for teaching (many of it's 'smart' features just get in the way).

That said, I'll probably look at VSCode as my first line -- I know it has good integration for RMarkdown/Quarto which I see as the biggest advantage of RStudio for teaching.

People have also pointed out https://r.analyticflow.com/en/ and https://www.getarchitect.io/, but I haven't looked at them beyond a cursory read of their sites.

title: Palantir and Posit Partner to Integrate RStudio into Palantir Foundry

last_post.content:
Wow. RStudio (recently rebranded as Posit) is partnering with Palantir. Yes, the same Palantir with ties to Cambridge Analytica. The same Palantir that partners with and actively supports ICE and other oppressive surveillance.

This is really not ok ethically, and can only mean a bad direction functionally for the company's software going forward. I never use RStudio for research myself, but it looks like I'll stop using it in teaching.

https://finance.yahoo.com/news/palantir-posit-partner-integrate-rstudio-115900656.html

#rstudio #palantir #posit #ice

title: Big Mystery Donors Fund Covid Conspiracy Nonprofit

last_post.content:
SCOOP: Tax filings reveal that the Brownstone Institute, a prolific, shadowy COVID misinformation group, is mostly funded by just 9 large donations.

Brownstone does not reveal its donor identities. The group's founder did not respond to our inquiry asking for even basic details about the contributions, which ranged from $25,000 to $600,000.

Read more at Important Context and subscribe for more stories!

The 'Bolza surface' is the most symmetrical Riemann surface that's topologically a 2-holed torus:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolza_surface

It consists of all complex solutions of

y² = x⁵ − x

and a point at infinity. If you map it to the Riemann sphere by sending (x,y) to x, you get a 2-sheeted branched cover of the sphere with branch points at the centers of the faces of a cube!

That's just what Tom Ruen got... without using complex analysis. I think this has got to be the same thing!

(2/n)

title: After self-hosting my email for twenty-three years I have thrown in the towel. The oligopoly has won.

last_post.content:
“The #fediverse is like #email.”

Yes.

Now read this and understand it:

“I have been self-hosting my email since I got my first broadband connection at home in 1999 … But my emails are just not delivered anymore. I might as well not have an email server.

Email is now an oligopoly, a service gatekept by a few big companies which does not follow the principles of net neutrality … I lost. We lost. One cannot reliably deploy independent email servers.“

https://cfenollosa.com/blog/after-self-hosting-my-email-for-twenty-three-years-i-have-thrown-in-the-towel-the-oligopoly-has-won.html

Via @cancel

title: What Companies Still Get Wrong About Layoffs

last_post.content:
Layoffs:
- don't save money
- don't improve company performance
- don't increase stock pricess
- destroy trust
- have huge impacts on health, well-being, and income of employees

So why do layoffs? It's a network effect: execs lay people off because other companies are doing it

Stanford Biz School article: https://news.stanford.edu/2022/12/05/explains-recent-tech-layoffs-worried/

Harvard Biz Review:
https://hbr.org/2022/12/what-companies-still-get-wrong-about-layoffs

title: a semester with the framework laptop

last_post.content:
Back at the beginning of my first semester at Texas A&M (a few days in), I received a Framework Laptop, a long-awaited purchase for me.

Spoiler alert: I absolutely love this thing.

I never got around to writing up the full review of it I planned to. Now that the semester is over, here's a review of how it performed over time. That should be an even better indicator than a "first impressions" post to anyone considering buying their own.

title: Thoughts on the Python packaging ecosystem

last_post.content:
I read this post on the current state of Python packaging with great interest because it's from someone who really understands and spends a lot of time in the Python open source/packaging ecosystem.

In all the time I've spend developing Python, a good 40%+ of my developer time has been spent trying to figure out how to ship and check code instead of writing it. There's no one easy solution, but maybe we could start with pip.

https://pradyunsg.me/blog/2023/01/21/thoughts-on-python-packaging/

title: GitHub - Fyrd/caniuse: Raw browser/feature support data from caniuse.com

last_post.content: If anyone did want to construct a more detailed history (trying to resist the urge for another project here) the caniuse repo has 9,208 commits stretching back a full 11 years - would absolutely be possible to assemble a detailed timeline for any feature that broke down exactly when it hit various support milestones using that data https://github.com/Fyrd/caniuse

Well that's embarrassing, I though https://caniuse.com didn't cover this but I just. Prices that if you click on the browser version numbers in the grid you get a popup box that tells you the browser release date - the exact thing I wanted to know

title: Peer Community In - free peer review & validation of preprints of articles

last_post.content:
Non-profit journals as a solution to open science?

Publishers charge researchers incredible amounts to remove paywalls from their own papers...and make unbelievable profits from doing so. Several have an >30% profit margin.

Initiatives such as @PeerCommunityIn provide an alternative: open access, non-profit journals that are free to publish in.

https://peercommunityin.org/
https://peercommunityjournal.org/
#OpenScience #Science #AcademicChatter @academicchatter
Graph (2013): @alexh https://alexholcombe.wordpress.com/2013/01/09/scholarly-publishers-and-their-high-profits/

title: Development of an open-source software for isomer enumeration - Journal of Cheminformatics

last_post.content:
today's Journal of Cheminformatics article https://jcheminf.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13321-022-00677-6 has CiTO annotation. As far as I know, it's the first one using a new CiTO pattern: cito:providesMethodFor

We've mostly seen cito:usesMethodIn... this articles describes in more detail a method that has been used in two articles, published in 2020 and 2021. This is not uncommon, but nice to see explicitly stated here :)

title: A Causal Link Between Facebook and Mental Health

last_post.content:
🎧 Podcast! The connection between Facebook and mental health is much studied, but a causal link to negative impacts is difficult to establish.

A new paper from Luca Braghieri, Roee Levy & Alexey Makarin establishes a causal link that may impact policy:
https://techpolicy.press/a-causal-link-between-facebook-and-mental-health/

Neat, just found out there's a relatively new "navigator.languages" array which returns the user's specified list of languages in preference order

It even has a "languagechange" event that fires when it changes!

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/languages

I always find it hard to track down exactly when features like this started to roll out, but it looks like support is pretty solid now:

https://caniuse.com/?search=navigator.languages
